casebody.data:
Emerson and Colette COLEMAN, Individually and on Behalf of the Minor Nakhia Coleman
v.
LOWERY CARNIVAL COMPANY, Crabtree Amusements, Inc., T.H.E. Insurance Company, and State Fair of Louisiana No. 2018-CC-403 Supreme Court of Louisiana. April 27, 2018

ON SUPERVISORY WRITS TO THE 1st JUDICAL DISTRICT COURT FOR THE PARISH OF CADDO

Writ denied. HUGHES, J., dissents and would grant and assigns reasons. Hughes, J., dissents and would grant the writ. Respectfully, this court should issue an order to cut through the stubbornness, obstructiveness, and inflexibility. All parties would be well served to place the best interests of the child ahead of their own. The examination of the eleven-year-old female child with possible brain injury should be conducted by Dr. Gary Mears in the child's hometown of Shreveport using the available reciprocal mirror with no one in the room except the doctor and the child, and videotaped. The trial court has the power to make this happen, and the parties should agree to it. Who benefits if the child is stressed out before the examination begins?
